inlineContent.text: CFMessagePort objects provide a communications channel that can transmit arbitrary data between multiple threads or processes on the local machine.
You create a local message port with
and make it available to other processes by giving it a name, either when you create it or later with
. Other processes then connect to it using
, specifying the name of the port.
To listen for messages, you need to create a run loop source with
and add it to a run loop with
If you want to tear down the connection, you must invalidate the port (using
) before releasing the runloop source and the message port object.
Your message portâ€™s callback function will be called when a message arrives. To send data, you store the data in a CFData object and call
. You can optionally have the function wait for a reply and return the reply in another CFData object.
Message ports only support communication on the local machine. For network communication, you have to use a

abstract.text: Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether a CFMessagePort object is valid and able to send or receive messages.
Returns the type identifier for the CFMessagePort opaque type.
Sets the callback function invoked when a CFMessagePort object is invalidated.
Returns the name with which a CFMessagePort object is registered.
Invalidates a CFMessagePort object, stopping it from receiving or sending any more messages.
Returns the invalidation callback function for a CFMessagePort object.
Schedules callbacks for the specified message port on the specified dispatch queue.
Returns a CFMessagePort object connected to a remote port.
Returns the context information for a CFMessagePort object.
Creates a CFRunLoopSource object for a CFMessagePort object.
Sends a message to a remote CFMessagePort object.

fragments.text: (CFMessagePort!, Int32, CFData!, CFTimeInterval, CFTimeInterval, CFString!, UnsafeMutablePointer<Unmanaged<CFData>?>!) -> Int32

abstract.text: Sets the name of a local CFMessagePort object.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether a CFMessagePort object represents a remote port.
Returns a local CFMessagePort object.
The CFFileDescriptor provides an opaque type to monitor file descriptors for read and write activity via CFRunLoop.

Callback invoked to process a message received on a CFMessagePort object.
A structure that contains program-defined data and callbacks with which you can configure a CFMessagePort objectâ€™s behavior.

CFStringTokenizer allows you to tokenize strings into words, sentences or paragraphs in a language-neutral way. It supports languages such as Japanese and Chinese that do not delimit words by spaces, as well as de-compounding German compounds. You can obtain Latin transcription for tokens. It also provides language identification API.
